content.webTitle: This Newcastle team are the most frustrating I have coached, says McClaren

fields.headline: This Newcastle team are the most frustrating I have coached – McClaren
fields.bodyText: Steve McClaren believes Newcastle United are the “most frustrating team” he has coached and he is demanding that his players overcome their “character flaws” at Stoke City on Wednesday night. With McClaren running out of time to reassure Mike Ashley, the owner, that he remains the right man to save Newcastle from relegation, he knows a significant improvement in the Potteries and at home against Bournemouth on Saturday is imperative. Since losing 5-1 at Chelsea Newcastle have had 17 days without a competitive game. They have returned from a training camp at La Manga in Spain with their manager under intense scrutiny from a board anxious to see the team move out of the bottom three. McClaren accepts this may be easier said than done. “This is the most frustrating team I’ve worked with,” he said. “We see fantastic performances from individuals one week and we look capable of beating anyone, then the next week it’s the polar opposite and we can lose by five or six goals. “That inconsistency is a character flaw we have got to put right. We’ve scored seven goals away, that’s the lowest number in the league and it’s not good enough. We have to start demonstrating character away from home. It’s about having courage. Too many times we’ve had things go against us in games and not reacted very well.” The prospect of missing out on next season’s lucrative Premier League TV-rights deal is concentrating minds in the St James’ Park boardroom. “It’s huge to make sure we stay in the League this season and we understand the severity of the situation we’re in. “The message we’ve been throwing at the players is that they have to realise the situation we’re in,” the former England coach said. “The severity and the seriousness of the situation is starting to get heightened and they can’t leave it until the last minute in the hope they’ll get out of it. “Seven goals away from home and two away wins is not good enough. Talent is not enough. We are losing too many games away from home and some of them we’re losing badly. We have to react better to setbacks, be harder, be tougher to beat and be ruthless. We have to start doing it now. We have to make sure we’re safe. We don’t want to be talking about what might have been.” After experimenting with assorted tactics and formations McClaren – who is considering making Jonjo Shelvey captain in place of the injured Fabricio Coloccini at Stoke – is convinced that the explanation for the erraticism lies in the players’ minds rather than on a training ground whiteboard. “Believe me, we’ve tried every formation and system of personnel you could imagine. One week we’re looking very strong and then the next we’re looking like we’re going to concede a lot of goals. It’s a mentality thing.” As Newcastle failed to insert relegation clauses – automatically reducing players’ wages by 50% should they drop into the Championship – into individual contracts, there is a suspicion certain players lack sufficient incentive to fight for survival. McClaren disagrees. “I really don’t believe that’s a factor. We’ve got very good individuals and when they click together we can beat anybody, but when they don’t we can lose to anybody.”
